results.title: One little indian
results.creator_credit: Grant Munro, Colin Low, Tom Daly and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A puppet film that wraps up some traffic safety rules in an absorbing story about a little Indian boy who pays his first visit to a big city. Even though Magic Bow is endowed with magic gifts and thrills the rodeo audience with his act, the whirl of traffic outside the arena leaves him completely bewildered. From kindly city folk he learns some basic safety precautions. (Presented with discussion in Window on Canada No. 69: How to Stay Alive on the Road, 106B 0156 132.) (Six awards, including Rapallo; New York.)

results.title: One lick method of fireline construction
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the technique of “progressive” fire line construction. Considers the organisation of the crew, arrangement of tools, instruction and use of an untrained crew to help fight a fire. Shows men working on a fire line, pointing out that lines can be too well defined; illustrates mopping up operations and compares the line method of fire fighting with older methods.

results.title: One Last Chance
results.brief_description: By focusing on the events experienced by a typical probation officer, over a period of about a week, this film aims to provide the public with a better understanding of the role and work of probation and parole officers; and show how the probation and parole system operates.

results.title: One kitten for Kim
results.creator_credit: Hector Lemieux, Joe Hayward and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description: Tells the story of a boy with seven kittens who is told by his parents that he may only keep one and must give the rest away. Encourages discussion of Kim’s adventures, the reactions of his parents and the experience of lower grade students of finding homes for pets. Suitable for lower primary level.

results.title: One in five
results.creator_credit: Peter Griffiths, David Evans and Millbank Films
results.brief_description: One in five people is likely to have a heart attack. We look at five people - a business executive, a roadworker, a switchboard operator, computer programmer and an electrician; and see why each one may be a candidate for a heart attack. Ways of preventing the risk of heart disease are discussed.

results.title: One in every hundred
results.creator_credit: Maurice Hatton, Richard De La Mare, Intertel and Rediffusion
results.brief_description: The problem of the mentally handicapped. Shows how parents and institutions cope with retarded children and adults, showing a wide range of situations in England and Canada. Special schools and adult training centres are shown, and it is emphasised that less severe cases are able to learn enough to support themselves and are better living in normal society than institutionalised.

results.title: One in a million
results.creator_credit: Government of Tasmania Department of Film Production
results.brief_description: An experiment in the fluoridation of drinking water by Beaconsfield Council, Tasmania. The local chemist was the driving force in having the Council add the necessary one part fluoride to a million parts of water. Comparisons over the years of teeth of children brought up on Council’s fluoridated water supply and the teeth of children from outlying areas using tank water amply justifies fluoridation. The benefit to general health, cost and lack of adverse effects on persons or industry.

results.title: One hundred harvests
results.creator_credit: Robert Hesselschwerdt and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: A historical review of the work done on cereal breeding since the establishment of the Department of Agriculture in 1872. Includes shots of many old farming implements housed in the Historical Museum of Jeparit. Shows stages in the development of new varieties of wheat at Werribee Research Farm. Made in connection with centenary of the Department.

results.title: One hundred entertainments
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of China”.
Based in Sian, on the old Silk Road to the west, the Shensi Provincial Acrobatic Troupe is skilled at their art, and loved by the people who see them perform. The Troupe’s tradition goes back two thousand years. It spends as much as eight months of the year on tour.
